skill.name: market-sizing-analysis
skill.description: This skill should be used when the user asks to calculate TAM, determine SAM, estimate SOM, size the market, calculate market opportunity, what's the total addressable market, or requests market sizing analysis for a startup or business opportunity.
skill.summary: Perform TAM, SAM, SOM market sizing analysis for startups and business opportunities using top-down, bottom-up, and value theory methodologies.
skill.author: wshobson

content.user_title: Calculate TAM, SAM, and SOM for startups
content.value_statement: Estimating market size is critical for startup strategy and fundraising but requires structured methodology. This skill provides frameworks for calculating Total Addressable Market, Serviceable Available Market, and Serviceable Obtainable Market using top-down, bottom-up, and value theory approaches.
actual_capabilities: Calculate Total Addressable Market using top-down analysis from industry reports
Calculate Total Addressable Market using bottom-up analysis from customer segments
Calculate Total Addressable Market using value theory based on willingness to pay
Narrow TAM to Serviceable Available Market with geographic and segment filters
Estimate Serviceable Obtainable Market with realistic capture rates
Present market sizing findings structured for investors or strategic planning
limitations: Does not access real-time market data or external databases
Does not validate assumptions against current market conditions
Does not perform competitive analysis beyond market sizing
Does not generate financial projections or business models

use_cases.title: Startup fundraising pitch preparation
use_cases.description: Prepare TAM, SAM, SOM analysis for investor pitch decks. Calculate realistic market opportunity using bottom-up methodology and present with data sources and conservative assumptions.

use_cases.title: New market entry strategy
use_cases.description: Evaluate whether a new market opportunity justifies entry. Define market boundaries, calculate addressable segments, and estimate achievable market share based on resources.

use_cases.title: Product-market fit validation
use_cases.description: Quantify the opportunity size for a specific product concept. Use value theory methodology to estimate willingness to pay and total market value for a proposed solution.

prompt_templates.title: Basic TAM calculation
prompt_templates.prompt: Calculate the Total Addressable Market for [PRODUCT/SERVICE] targeting [CUSTOMER SEGMENT] in [GEOGRAPHY]. Use bottom-up methodology: estimate the number of potential customers, average revenue per customer, and provide TAM, SAM, and SOM with your assumptions documented.
prompt_templates.scenario: Quick market sizing request with limited context

prompt_templates.title: SaaS market sizing
prompt_templates.prompt: Perform complete market sizing analysis for a B2B SaaS product serving [INDUSTRY] companies with [ANNUAL REVENUE THRESHOLD]. Include: 1) Top-down estimate from industry reports, 2) Bottom-up estimate from target company counts and ACV, 3) SOM estimate with realistic capture rates. Show triangulation between methods and document all data sources.
prompt_templates.scenario: Detailed SaaS market analysis for VC pitch

prompt_templates.title: Value theory calculation
prompt_templates.prompt: Use value theory methodology to estimate market size for [INNOVATIVE PRODUCT/SERVICE]. The product solves [PROBLEM] with estimated time savings of [HOURS] per user at [ hourly rate]. Calculate TAM based on total addressable customers, willingness to pay at 20% of value created, and applicable market segments.
prompt_templates.scenario: New market category without existing data

prompt_templates.title: Multi-year SOM projection
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a 5-year SOM projection for [PRODUCT] entering [MARKET]. Start with TAM of [AMOUNT], apply realistic SAM filters, then estimate Year 1, Year 3, and Year 5 SOM based on typical new entrant capture rates. Include assumptions about go-to-market resources and competitive response.

output_examples.input: Calculate TAM for an AI-powered code review tool for mid-market software companies in North America
output: - Target: Mid-market software companies (50-1000 employees) in North America
- Estimated count: 25,000 companies (source: Census Bureau, industry reports)
Key assumptions: Conservative penetration rates reflect new entrant challenges and competitive landscape.

output_examples.input: Use value theory to estimate market size for a productivity tool that saves knowledge workers 2 hours per week at average hourly rate of $50
output: - Time savings: 2 hours/week Ã— 52 weeks = 104 hours/year
- Target: Knowledge workers in US (approx. 50 million)
Key assumptions: Willingness to pay at 15% of value created is based on comparable SaaS pricing models.

best_practices: Use bottom-up analysis as primary method since it is most credible for investors and can be defended with customer data
Triangulate between top-down and bottom-up methods - results should be within 30% to indicate reasonable assumptions
Document all data sources, assumptions, and calculations clearly for transparency and future validation
anti_patterns: Using TAM as the entire addressable market without applying realistic product or geographic constraints
Setting SOM too aggressive - new entrants rarely capture more than 5% market share in 5 years
Using only top-down analysis without validating with customer-level bottom-up calculations

faq.question: What is the difference between TAM, SAM, and SOM?
faq.answer: TAM is the total market opportunity if achieving 100% market share. SAM is the portion targetable with current product capabilities. SOM is the realistic market share achievable in 3-5 years accounting for competition and resources.

faq.question: Which methodology should I use for my startup?
faq.answer: Bottom-up is preferred for most situations as it is most credible to investors. Use top-down when established market research exists. Use value theory for new market categories without existing data.

faq.question: How do I calculate SOM for a new startup?
faq.answer: Start with SAM, then apply realistic capture rates of 2-5% for years 3-5. Account for competition, resources, go-to-market effectiveness, and time to market.

faq.question: What data sources should I use for market sizing?
faq.answer: Top-down: industry reports from Gartner, Forrester, IDC. Bottom-up: customer interviews, LinkedIn data, Crunchbase, industry databases. Value theory: ROI studies and willingness-to-pay surveys.

faq.question: How do I present market sizing to investors?
faq.answer: Lead with bottom-up calculation, show triangulation with top-down, explain conservative assumptions, link to revenue projections, and highlight market growth drivers.

faq.question: What is a realistic SOM for a new entrant?
faq.answer: Most new entrants capture 2-5% of SAM within 3-5 years. Anything above 10% without significant resources or competitive advantage is typically viewed skeptically by investors.
